thread.title: Dallas' Johny Hendricks reportedly rushed to ER; Dana White says he's out of UFC 192
thread.title_full: Dallas' Johny Hendricks reportedly rushed to ER; Dana White says he's out of UFC 192 | Dallas Morning News

author: Joshua Friemel
title: Dallas' Johny Hendricks reportedly rushed to ER; Dana White says he's out of UFC 192
text:
The top-ranked welterweight contender Johny Hendricks won't be fighting Tyron Woodley in UFC 192 after weight cut issues forced him out, UFC Dana White president tweeted just a day before the fight.
Hendricks vs Woodley is off the card due to Hendricks weight cut issues. pic.twitter.com/By3P6jg2FO
â” Dana White (@danawhite) October 2, 2015 Hendricks was rushed to the ER last night.
Hendricks' manager tells me Johny had a blockage in intestine and kidney stone. Rushed to ER last night.
â” Brett Okamoto (@bokamotoESPN) October 2, 2015 In an interview with mmafighting.com , Hendricks told Ariel Helwani about his trip to the emergency room.
"The weight was coming off fine and then yesterday my body just started to shut down," Hendricks told Helwani. "When it hit that point, I tried to push through it, and well, it didn't go well because then I had to go to the ER."
Just two days ago, Hendricks told The Dallas Morning News that he was, "in a lot better place now" in terms of cutting weight before the bout.
When Hendricks lost his title belt to Robbie Lawler at UFC 181 last December, Hendricks had a weight cut that was so bad that he considered retiring.
Hendricks stopped working with nutritionist Mike Dolce after that fight. Dolce sent this out shortly after White tweeted the news about Hendricks.
Sad to hear. I hope Johny is ok. " @danawhite : Hendricks vs Woodley off the card due to Hendricks weight cut issues. pic.twitter.com/Q2kdFaK3zw "
â” Mike DOLCE (@TheDolceDiet) October 2, 2015 Before Hendricks' bout with Matt Brown at UFC 185, which was the first fight he had after that horrible weight cut, he talked with Ariel Helwani about why he chose to not partner with Dolce anymore (at the 5:09 mark).
Hendricks recently told the Morning News that the incident at UFC 181 nearly knocked him into retirement. However, he said that the incident did change his career for the better.
"Now it can further my career instead of me walking away," he said Wednesday. "I might have had one fight left in me. If I win that fight [against Robbie Lawler], I don't change my diet. We probably don't change everything that we are doing. The next fight, the same thing happens and I'm probably like, 'Dude. Screw it. I'm done. I don't want to cut weight like that.' That's where I was at after that fight. It was 50-50. Fifty percent that I was going to quit and retire or fifty percent that I was going to continue to do it. We ended up sticking with it."
Before UFC 185, Hendricks spoke with the Morning News' Mark Francescutti about how he cut weight before fights. The following comes from his story, which can be found in its entirety here :
He [Hendricks] will sit in a hot tub for 20 minutes, take a short break to dip in a cold pool, then go back into the hot tub. The process could take several hours to lose 10-12 pounds.
"I go up and hot tub with him," Christina Hendricks, his wife, said. "It sounds like it might be OK, but even 15 minutes in, you're sweating so bad, you're like, 'Get me out of there.'"
